description:
This is the most delicious pizza you will ever get from a food truck...and 95% of most brick and mortar pizza restaurants.

The pizza is Neapolitan style, cooked perfectly (with deliciously chewy crust), and high-quality ingredients. The pizza is also prepared/cooked quickly (less than 5-10 min). You can make your pizza vegan by omitting cheese...the pizza is so good that won't miss it.
author: Christina M.

description:
I LOVE Del Popolo's pizza. I am not a big pizza eater, as I usually find it to be very heavy and oily, but man, id Del Popolo's amazing. They have refined their crust to perfection - its super soft, beautifully blistered for awesome texture, and every last bite is light and tasty.  

The toppings are always generous, perfectly balanced and distributed, and you can tell they use really quality ingredients, as the flavors seem to burst forth in each bite.  

I have sought out both the physical location and the food truck several times since first coming here, and each time they do not disappoint.  Also, their staff is always super friendly and professional. The last time, I'm sorry to say, I was in an argument with my boyfriend and our server took me off guard with a question, so I ended up very curtly answering him.  The entire night though, he was still friendly and composed. So sorry and it won't happen again - keep being great Del Popolo fam!
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Three of us came here for dinner on a Saturday night (restaurant, not food truck) and shared a couple of appetizers, three individual pizzas and a couple of desserts. It's a really mixed experience:

(1). The broccolini and the kale salad were great.
(2).  Our server recommended the margherita, the Bianca and salami pizzas with the house made sausage and peppers as toppings for the margherita.  The main issue for me was that the pizza crust was doughy and soggy (it's not what I would expect from a wood fire oven).  It was a real let down after the great appetizers. 
(3).  The desserts were OK - the creme fraiche panna cotta and a split order of chocolate ice cream and blackberry-lime sorbet (these two flavors and consistencies went really well together).
(4).  Service was good and the food came out fast. 
(5).  The ambiance was good - it's nice to see a restaurant centered around a wood fire oven.  

Overall, this is a 3.5 rating but I rounded down because of the pizza dough (it's a pizza place after all). The above meal plus a glass of wine each plus tax plus tip cost about $60 per person. I would not recommend this place but I'm glad I checked this place out.

P.S.  The owner reached out to me and he explained to me that the Neapolitan-style pizza is intentionally soft.
author: Andrew S.

description: I highly recommend reservations. What an amazing experience! Every morsel of food was a delightful sensory experience. Even though the restaurant was busy and full, the staff was friendly and warm. Dining here was the highlight of my visit to San Francisco.
author: Jenn H.

description: Amazing pizza. Wow.  The crust  is perfect - nice char and pillowy soft and beautifully topped.  The pizza is king here but all the apps are delicious as well so don't skip those.  Wish I lived a little closer
author: hary n.

description:
I think the Del Popolo Pizza Truck is an ingenious idea, in order to be able to create some of the best tasting Neapolitan-style pizza pies in the Bay Area, owner Jon Darsky successfully figured out a way to put a five thousand pound pizza oven in a food truck! As you approach the mobile food truck, you'll immediately notice that this is no truck at all but it's a giant shipping-container-on-wheels with one wall of completely built of windows, so you can look inside as the crew cooks pizzas in their massive wood-fired oven as you look to see what you should order of their menu. Overall the huge rig feels like it's a statement on the overall realm of design as it does on the modern day food delivery system.

I had the opportunity to see the Del Popolo pizza truck at a family member's wedding recently, guess the bride and groom were such fans of their authentic Neapolitan-style pizzas that they had to host their wedding guests with this specialized pizza truck. Everything with the Del Popolo truck was extremely organized as they arrived early and parked themselves outside of the San Francisco Film Center in the Presidio and they set up and organized as they were ready to serve plenty of pizza from 4-6pm. And for the next two hours the pizza just kept coming out again and again. Since this was a pre-arranged deal that the wedding couple set up we could only go with four pizza options but there was no need to stand in line to order, it became an easier task just to wait in line for the crew to just put out the pies on the ledge in front of their truck, and there were no more than three present at all times, all different pizzas and all piping hot fresh from that huge pizza oven.

We got a chance to try four of their signature pies including their hallowed Margherita with crushed tomato, mozzarella, basil, the Housemade Sausage pizza with crushed tomato, mozzarella, fennel sausage, gypsy pepper, red onion and Calabrian chili, the Market pizza with roasted pepper, caramelized onions, San Andreas sheep's cheese, salame di manzo and thyme and a uniquely made to order Pork Salami pizza. Although I loved all of the options they gave us, and trust me I am no pizza neophyte, my personal favorite was the Housemade Sausage pizza because of the perfect pairing of the fennel sausage, red onions and Calabrian chili all made for a delectable highlight. All of the pizzas they cooked at Del Popolo had the perfect amount of char on the bottom to each pie that made everything well cooked and tasting refined. Topped with optional Parmesan cheese and red chili pepper, every pie tasted full of sublime character and flavor. 

I've had my eye on Del Popolo pizza for some time and now that I've had the opportunity to try out a sample of the freshly baked pies they offer on their food truck, I can't wait to go to their brick and mortar restaurant on Bush Street in San Francisco's lower Nob Hill area. Owner Jon Darsky clearly had the intention of making authentic Neapolitan-style pizzas in a wood-fired oven that could hit extremely high temperatures, and it's nice to know that he insisted on not  compromising on that vision when he decided to start with a mobile operation. This way every pizza lover can mangia on their own to see what kind of pizza pie tickles their fancy when it's cooked to perfection.
author: Jason F.

description: Really delicious pizza but if you have a party over 8 it's a 900 dollar minimum.  So 100 per person for pizza. Not cool guys not cool. Why you gotta do that. Let the people eat.
author: Juan O.

description:
Chose to try this place at the park presidio picnic. The line was super long, it took about 40 minutes in total. Wasn't completely worth the wait. 

We got a margarita pizza, half of it with pepperoni. The pizza was good, just not the best pizza I've ever had. Wish it had more cheese on it. I really liked the crust and the tomato sauce.

Would come back, just wouldn't wait in a long line for this.
author: Hayley D.

description: They catered our wedding this past weekend. They did an incredible job! What an amazing truck! They not only served the pizzas quickly, but they also took into account allergies efficiently.
author: Julian T.

description: Outstanding service and clean bathroom! Probably the cleanest we had been in out of all the places we went to eat in SF. Our waiter was very accommodating, and gave us excellent service. It was a laid back atmosphere. The pizza was so delicious.. and the wine was even better.
author: Naicee S.

description:
Loved their food truck! I have been to the lace many times but my pizza dough comes uncooked most of the times and doughy. I have been to all vpn pizzerias in the Bay Area and top ones at Napoli, Italy so I don't expect tons on cheese, but they have to add some grams on their pies.
Staff is polite but not warm. Nice vibe .
Love the panettone from Roy
author: Annie T.

description: Terrible experience a few months back. The individual working the food truck at the presidio Sunday event was extremely rude. Pizza itself was mediocre.
author: Michael C.

description:
I randomly stumbled upon Del Popolo once when they were parked outside of Blue Bottle on a week day near Mint Plz. 

I was pretty hungry, and realizing that I would rather pay $10-$12 for some kind of pizza versus $8 for a pastry I opted to stand in line. The pizza was quick and the line moved even quicker. I really enjoyed the extreme freshness of everything. This truly was a very, very made on the spot kind of pizza. 

I got Margherita ... because this is the type of occasion one gets such a pizza. It was amazing. The sauce had a great tanginess to it, and the pizza was doughy, soft but firm and delicious to the bite. Definitely grab a pizza from this truck when you get a chance!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Fancier pizza truck on wheels that stops by Mint Plaza on Thursdays. It's $12-$13 for a perfectly sized personal pizza and $0.50 for the covered to go box. I decided to forgo my diet for a special team outing. Ordered, warm service and recognized my teammates as regulars by name. Pretty quick too, not a few minutes until my pizza was ready. 

My Italian coworker approved of this place but agreed that the pizza wasn't up to par as the previous times they had it. He was also critical of mascarpone as a cheese topping on the special pizza and skeptical about the bacon and squash. 

I got the Margherita. Mmm doughey goodness and flavor though the texture was off. The crust never achieved that bubbly flakey light crispiness I sometimes dream of in Neapolitan pizza and my friends rave about as Del Popolo's characteristic. Crust was limp and gummy even on the thick outer edges, like it was underdone. The bottom had a slightly burnt bitter char. Toppings tasted great but watery, I preferred the freshness and uncooked nature of the crushed tomato and basil. 

On the second time, I opted for the Bianca instead which was better than the first experience and more flavorful. The crust was crispier, less chewy but slightly burnt. It was light and had a naan like consistency. The cheese toppings and basil were subtle, mildly creamy but there wasn't a lot of them and they sank towards the center. I'd definitely get the Bianca over the Margherita again.

The quantity was just right. The pizza didn't leave me in a carby food coma state like a heavy sandwich does or the competing Acai bowl truck that gives me the sugar rush jitters. Highlights are the quality ingredients and fresh out of the oven experience. Crust was a letdown, if it were more consistently cooked it'd be a 4 and perhaps it was an off day.
author: Truc N.

description:
We encountered this truck at an Off The Grid event at the Presidio. I'm not sure if this is a recurring event, and whether it typically includes the same participants. 

The line at Del Popolo was one of the longest, so we almost didn't try it, but I'm so glad we did! 

The pizza had that thin/foldable crust like the best Brooklyn NY pizzas, and a tangy, fresh sauce. We only tried the Margherita pizza, and it was so good that I wouldn't bother trying anything else! 

I just wish we lived in SF, so we could seek out this food truck on a regular basis.
author: Tara C.

description: The food was tasty and the service was ok. My only complaint is that the pizza dough wasn't fully cooked so the pizzas we ordered were doughy.
author: Brian B.

description:
I've seen this pizza truck around San Francisco for years and never braved the long lines that always accompany it's existence. That being said, Del Popolo was at the opening of SF Beer Week on Pier 35 and guess what? There was no line! Woo Hoo! 

Let's be frank here. It's an incredible feat that they were able to fit an oven, kitchen and 3-4 employees in this truck. Mind boggling actually. 

I love the simplicity of the menu, limited beer list and concentration on doing a few things well rather than a bunch of disjointed products. I opted for the standard margarita pizza, which was heavenly. The crust was exceptional. The red sauce was just like pizzas from Napoli, also exceptional. 

I suppose the moral of the story is, I'll be waiting in the long line the next time I see Del Popolo firing their insane pizzas. A tip of the hat to you sir.
author: Benjamin F.

description: The truck is so cool looking from the outside, and I really wanted to like their pizza... but just like their brick and mortar, the pizza is really very wet, both for the vegetarian and meat version. The dough itself has good texture, which makes it very unfortunate that it looses all of that with all the sauce that gravitates towards the center of the pizza.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
What a food truck! The design and concept alone lure you into standing in their long line.  The wood-fired oven inside the truck is really cool to see, but even better produces that bubbly, crisp crust adding depth of flavor and texture.

Selection is limited, but you can't go wrong with the Bianca. The freshness of the ricotta and mozzarella really shine on this simple pie.

However for the Magherita, the description which states "crushed tomatoes" is pretty much what you get. Rather than a tomato sauce, simmered for hours with herbs and  garlic, it tastes like the juice from freshly crushed tomatoes. For most people, they'll -appreciate it. I prefer cooked tomatoes, so I wasn't a fan. It also made the pizza a bit watery and the acidic flavor was overwhelming the basil and mozzarella.
author: Lindsey C.

description: Had the margarita pizza, never knew a pizza with so few ingredients could taste that good (there really isn't much sauce or anything on it though). I thoroughly enjoyed the airy crust.
author: Raymond J.

description:
3.5 STARS

Took advantage of my Friday night at Outside Lands and decided to finally try Del Popolo! Since pizzas are make to order on the truck, the line moved a little slow. But I didn't mind since I was really excited to try their Margherita pizza!

For Outside Lands, they were only serving the Margherita (crushed tomatoes, mozzarella, basil) at $12 each. They offered one option for extras. Pork salami for an additional $3. I stuck with the regular Margherita since I just wanted something simple. 

The pizza came out bubbly and hot! The crust was nice and chewy and had a great crisp to it! I also loved the mozzarella and basil! The one thing I didn't care for was the tomato sauce. It was a little too sweet and acidic for me. My first bite was a little jarring due to the sauce. But I loved the crust, mozzarella & basil so much, I kept eating the pizza while trying to brush away the sauce. Yes, it got a little messy, but all those elements were that good!

The truck itself is gorgeous! Glass windows on the side so you can see the pizza making action! It's got a great rustic feel with the brown frame coloring while adding a dash of contemporary flair with the numerous glass windows.

I would love to stop by this truck again so I can try some of the other pizzas they offer. Since I've read so many good things about their margherita, I may give that another shot too. Maybe it was the music festival, but hopefully the crushed tomatoes won't disappoint the next time!
author: Elena N.

description:
They catered our company Christmas party and did a great job! All the pizzas were tasty and hot served fresh! 
Thanks again guys and gals for the hard work and prompt times.
author: Charles F.

description:
April 13, 2014 Sunday - lunch 11:15 AM
3 adult

Atmosphere - 5 stars
Food - 5 stars
Service - 5 stars 

Background - I have been eyeing this truck for over a year.  I do not even remember how I found out about the truck.  We were heading to Walt Disney Museum and the bonus was truck is there today!  But this ain't your normal pizza truck, this is a Napoli style pizza truck.
 
Atmosphere - Part of the Off the Grid event at the Presidio.  We got there early and had lunch so the lines were not much at all.  Some of the trucks had none.  By the time we got done at the museum the lines were 20 to 30 people deep for all the trucks.

Food
  Drinks - none, I got mine at the Off the Grid bar.

  Appetizer - none.

  My Main Course - We ordered two pizzas for the three of us.  Bianca is free of a red sauce which is just mozzarella and ricotta cheese and basil and garlic.  It was good, but the Margherita had me.  It is classic and they nailed.  The golden crust to the mozzarella on the crushed tomatoes had me.  I could have finished off one of those pines on my own.

  Dessert - none.

Service - The line might look long, okay it is, but they know how to work it.  While you are in line they take your order so when you get to the cashier/server they have them for you.  Really since they are only making two types of pizza they just need a ballpark idea.  They cut your pizza in front while you are settling your bill.

Future - I would love to hunt down this trunk again for a snack.  Like I said in an early review there are so many choices in SF I still need to try.
author: Paul S.

description:
Some of the best crispy chewy pizza crust around. The toppings aren't that interesting but I guess it's better that way to not distract from the crust. 

$13 or so will get you a personal sized pizza that won't be too filling.
author: Jean K.

description:
Woohoo! Apparently the best food truck pizza in America according to some wine and food magazine as told to me by my coworker. We headed out to get some pizza from Del Popolo's wood oven food truck which happened to be near my office in the city.

The line was rather long and it was a pretty windy day, so we were all having doubts about whether the wait would be worth it. Well, it definitely was!! The pizza was incredibly good, and I'm still amazed that it came out of a food truck, albeit a highly modified one!

The menu is rather "limited". I ordered the Margherita pizza with additional salami toppings (+$3) to go (+$0.50) since it was too windy to eat out. The crust was super thind and soft, it tasted more like a super fluffy and soft flat bread instead of the usual thick/ sometimes crunch crust of American pizzas. The sides of the crust was burnt, just the way it is supposed to be. Ahhh, finger lickin good :)

I'm not usually a big fan of pizzas, but I'm Definitely coming back for more!
author: Christina N.

description:
Rare in San Francisco to find a place that not only has perfect pizzas, amazing appetizers
and a lovely, friendly, attentive staff. Add to this that the prices are not SF crazy but within reach. We enjoyed every single thing we ordered. You cannot go wrong here. It's all good.
Find four people to go and they will take a reservation so you won't have to wait.
author: Chris V.

description:
Food: awesome. Had the app with squid. Best dish of the night actually. Had the pizza with sausage and ... Veggie and honey? You don't think it's good but it's really good. A tiny bit of sweetness really does it. 

Atmosphere: ok. The seating with swivel tiny round seats are not that comfy. But food was good and it wasn't too packed together so I dug it.

Damn it. Think I posted it to their old food truck.
author: P L.

description:
I'm picky about pizza. I don't care how much it cost, because when it's good. It's GOOD.

1) The aesthetics of this food truck is on fleek! Whoa. The first time I saw it, I had to snap chat it and show all my friends what a cool place I'm eating at (or more like "around"). Plus, the guys in the truck waved at me while I took the video!

2) Taste was fabulous. Luckily I was at an event where they were catering and I lost my mind. They had three varieties for the event: margherita, bianca, and an asparagus one. My favorite has to be the bianca! WOW. I am lactose intolerant, but you know what, everyone's gotta have those weak moments. 

You need to go!
author: Amy H.

description: We hired their pizza truck for a backyard event and they were awesome! Great service, food, and set up. We didn't have to clean up or do much except just wait for the pizza to come out. I highly recommend having them at your next party.
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
BBAPT.  That stands for Big Bad Ass Pizza Truck!  Which is essentially what Del Popolo is!

I've been wanting to check out Del Popolo ever since I saw an article on the web profiling their $180,000 custom built Wood Burning Oven Pizza Truck (http://bit.ly/15grEbS).  It's really an impressive sight to see when you see them in action.  I finally got to try them when they were at Off The Grid at Pier 29.

They have a simple pizza menu with 4 or 5 specialties.  The one that really caught my eye was their Bianco which is a White Pizza with basil, ricotta, garlic, white sauce.
http://bit.ly/XSSsSa 
Can you say YUM???  It was very good pizza!  If you've ever had the White Pizza at Secret Pizza at the Cosmopolitan in Las Vegas, it's pretty similar in taste.  The Ricotta's creamy, and the basil and garlic make the pizza explode with flavor!  It's also a pretty decent sized pie for $12 and is very competitively priced with all the artisan pizza joints in SF.

Considering that I've only had one pizza, I can't say it's the best in SF.  But considering that they're cranking out serious artisan pies out of a wood oven in a trailer, they're definitely right up there with the likes of Tony's and Delfina.  I hope to see this truck again soon to try their other pies!
author: Rodney H.

description:
This place is the TITS! I used to walk by here on the way to work and got really excited when i saw the big ceramic pizza oven being installed. 

I FINALLY went here on a double date this past weekend and now I want to go back every day. 

Not only were the pizza's awesome but the app's were also yummy. Melon Salad with a perfect balance of sweet and salty. Farrotto, which i could have ate the whole thing myself, was rich with flavor and the yolk added that extra pow.

We had 3 pizza's but my favorite was the Butterball Potato with honey! A must buy!
author: Scott L.

description:
Great pizza! But totally weak pours for beer. The glasses hold, at most, 10 ounces, but you're charged 8-10 bucks as if it were an upscale pint. 

And wine comes in a half-full tulip on a stem!
author: Evan A.

description:
Tried out Del Popolo Pizza Truck on Sun 9/16/12 since they are usually never open on weekends, they were in Hayes Valley for the Urban Air Market held twice a yr: Spring & Fall.

There was a short line only 4 people ahead of me after 11:30am so I got in line.  They only had 3 choices:

Margherita - tomato, basil, mozzarella $11

White - ricotta, mozzarella, basil, garlic $12

Meat - wild boar salami, kale, mozzarella, chiles $15

I got the meat.  Charged it since they take credit cards.  Got it in a few minutes.  It was 4 big slices, enough for 2 to share or 1 hungry person.  My pizza was blackened on the top, about 9 slices of boar salami, & some mozzarella cheese.  It wasn't that good!

I was hoping for a good pizza, I'll keep looking.  If you get it to eat on the street you get a pie pan w/ wax paper on top of it & pizza on top of the wax paper.  If you To-Go they put it in a Cardboard Box.
author: Ann L.

description:
They showed up to the 2nd Annual Sunnyvale Fry's Food Truck. The truck itself is very impressive with it's large windows and wood burning oven. The food and service? Eh.. not so much.

What we swallowed:

PEPPERONI PIZZA: The pizza came out piping hot.. but was runny and soggy. Why? I don't really like soggy pizza.. what more piping hot and runny. The sauce was tasty but a bit watery and my whole slice was just a pile of mush. Then the edges.. it's not like cool, crispy give-it-that-smokey-flavor burnt taste, this ish was straight up nasty and tasted like charcoal. My friend that bought the Blanca pizza had told us (even before we sat down to eat it) "You'll need to peel off the burnt bubbles. They ruin the taste." I thought he was just being a picky mitch but yeah, it was kinda gross. They were even pretty scrimpy on the pepperoni too... eight pieces on a large? Really? My slice had a lucky sliver of pepperoni on it! That's it! 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/del-popolo-san-francisco?select=7dznR8vEmz_NK1aggqpFBg#7dznR8vEmz_NK1aggqpFBg

Not worth the $12 for the pizza.

My friend wanted to add another topping and they were pretty rude about not having substitutions. He even offered for them to charge him for it and they were pretty adamant about the "NO!" What's one more topping? It's not rocket science!

We all agreed the ingredients tasted fresh and the pizza had a lot of potential, they just have to practice more on cooking the pizza better.

Pizza pass.
author: Vivian A.

description:
I love the concept of this gigantic food truck, with a restaurant quality pizza oven imported from Naples. It's the largest and most expensive pizza truck ever built (14 tons, +$180K). http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/4QCLCmAkAcgDAvK-ov1r6w/l.jpg

It's cool that the glass panels let u see the entire operation at work. http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ttsLdrsKe24vXZcmZXcZ4g/l.jpg The 800 degree oven cooks a pizza in one minute. There were some people ahead of me, so I had to wait about 12-15 minutes after placing my order. http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/DIKVO78KvRKVz6GlnQfYfA/l.jpg But if you're expecting to get a pizza like Tony's, then u might be disappointed. The crust is like super fluffy naan bread, and mine had a significantly charred bottom. Too soft and a bit too burnt for my taste. Worth only 2-3 stars, if compared to other SF pizzas. I saved half to take home for later. It was much better when crisped by my toaster oven.

There's only 2 pizzas on the menu: Marguerita or Blanca for $10 each. Drinks are $2.

Hours: 11am-2pm, at various locations. Check Twitter for location updates.
Regular weekly stops include:
- Sydney Walton Square park (on Jackson and Front Street, near Kokkari, across the street from Safeway)
- Mint Plaza
- in front of Bar Agricole restaurant.

** Update: About 2 months after my original review the short menu was revised, and prices went up to $12-$15 each. The new meat pizza ($15) was too salty. The only decent tasting one is the white pizza with ricotta and mozzarella. Like I said before, their pizza dough is too soft and too burnt for my taste. I prefer Tony's or Cupola Pizzeria for Neapolitan pizzas.
author: Luis C.

description:
I love a good Neopolitan pizza and SF is home to many of my favorites. I've been seeing things about Del Popolo and the owner online and I immediately made plans to try them on their first official day.

$7 for their Margherita was a lot lower than I had expected since I read that it was $10 on their site so it might have been a promotional pricing. Their behemoth of a truck was parked at Bar Agricole and from there we were allowed to utilize their outdoor seats/area to eat our pizza. I'm not sure if this is going to be one of their regular spots but I liked the location. 

Pizzas were made incredibly quick and the crust were perfectly blistered from their wood burning oven that they were able to secure inside this truck. 

Del Popolo, I will be seeing you again very soon.
author: Esther A.

description: Had the Cesar salad w squash and trumpet mushroom small plates. Enjoyed both but not sure the raw squash added much to the salad. Split the house sausage pizza and the margherita w spicy salami. Both came out with the majority of the outer crust and bottom burnt.  Burnt black. Unfortunately it gave the pizza a bitter taste. I was seated near the oven and it seemed as though all the pizzas we're coming out similarly well done. We had three beers, solid IPA's, which went well w the pizzas but were small pours ( I think they list them as 10.5 ounce pours). So for a party of four, 3 beers, 2 small plates, and 2 pizzas for 94 dollars. Overall, disappointed.
author: S W.

description:
YUM YUM YUM! I just had Del Popolo over the weekend at Outside Lands. The whole weekend I held off on eating pizza until I had it from here. Finally figured out where it was for the last day. The line was pretty long and we waited about 30 minutes before finally getting to devour our pizzas.

My friend and I both ordered their Margherita pizza which was absolutely delicious. Although there was a wait, it was worth it and actually not that bad since there was music and chatting going on. Once I had my pizza in hand, I was happily dancing to music while munching on pizza.

When I first heard that they were at OSL and it was the pizza to try, I was surprised I hadn't heard of the restaurant before. Then when we finally found it, I realized they're a food truck! A friggen awesome food truck at that.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I had Del Popolo at their truck at OSL 2014. The first thing that impressed me was the truck itself. Its not like a regular food truck... Del Popolo's truck is huge, and very clean, modern and pretty!


I shared a margherita pizza with my girlfriend which was totally good. I loved the fresh ingredients and how simple and well prepared it was. The pizza costs us about $10, which seemed a little too much for the size... but whatever... festival prices I guess lol.

Despite the price, I would get the margherita pizza again, and perhaps try other variations. Thanks!
author: Felicia L.

description: Hot Damn, Pizza time!  We waited 45 minutes at Outsidelands  for this pizza, and it was pretty worth it.  All things considered we were kind of drunk and made friends in line so that helped pass the time.  Their crust really stands out here, great chewy texture and good flavor.  Tried the Margherita with added salumi came out to $15.  It's great that the pizza just comes straight out of the oven right to your face, pipping hot.  I was pleasantly surprised that they didn't jack up the prices for the concert, maybe because they're "the people";s pizza as their name suggests, thanks.  Can't wait to try their white pizza next.
author: Spencer W.

description:
Potrero Hill never ceases to amaze me with their dining options -- I'm looking at you, Chez Maman and Papito. 

Del Popolo is no exception.

I went there today for lunch with some work friends. Word to the wise : get there at noon or a little earlier. They move pies like nobody's business, but if you get there any later than 12:20, chances are you'll be waiting for 30-40 minutes if there's more than 12-15 ppl in line.

They take card (woo!) and they're polite and efficient. Now on to the good stuff: I had the Bianca ($13) and I added pepperoni ($3). In just 10 minutes tops, I was enjoying the most delightful, perfectly charred thin crust wood fired pie. Piping hot with just right amount of ricotta -- it was perfection. Honestly, it's easily the best pie I've had in SF so far. You can buy a to-go box if you can't finish it... but you'll probably finish it.

Tuesdays only -- set your reminders now.
author: Katie A.

description:
I was real skeptical about this truck. But just looking at the thought that went into the design of this truck I thought maybe their pizza is equally well thought out. So let's give it a try.

Gosh dang!! This pizza is good. Good good good good. Probably the best pizza I've had in SF since coming from the east coast last year. Crust is perfect! Seared just right but still chewy with the thin bubbles. The bubbles man! Man this brings me back to some joints in NYC. Fresh mozz. The oven is probably the star of the show here. Nailed it. 

I'm ashamed to say, but I'm a NYer who loves pizza from a truck.
author: Augusto M.

description:
70 degrees + 2 Pizza and Food Truck Fans + 1 Sunny Drive to the Presidio +

Many Long Lines + 2 Empanadas to Tide Us Over + Interesting People Watching + 1 Crazy Cool Shipping Container Transformed Into Wood Fired Pizza Oven on 4 Wheels + 50 (?!?) Minutes Later +

(Mozzarella + Arugula Rapini + Pecorino + Blistered and Soft Crust + $12 = 1 Bianca Pizza) + Wish for Margherita + 

(Mozzarella + Roasted Potato + Pancetta + Green Garlic + Blistered and Soft Crust + $14 = 1 Meat Pizza) =

OFF THE GRID PICNIC AT THE PRESIDIO 2013

http://offthegridsf.com/picnic
author: Amy C.

description:
(See pics) Review #1331. Okay pizza but I still do not like the burnt edges. Slightly charred is not the same as burnt as burnt gave a very bitter taste. The wild boar salami was a nice kick to the pizza.

They served Mexican coke, which was always an excellent choice with pizzas.

Do hope that it's absolutely safe to drive around with such a big oven.
author: T L.

description:
There's no more contentious topic than "What's the best pizza in SF?" Just wait for an argument, a fistfight, or even a war break out over this topic. Take any group of SF residents, ask this question, and you'll NEVER come to a unanimous decision on this topic.

Well, guess what. I'm laying down the hammer. Del Popolo has the best pizza in SF. In fact, I think it has the best pizza, ANYWHERE.

Perfectly soft-and-yet-chewy crust, with the perfect amount of charcoal taste. Fresh ingredients. The perfect, not-overpowering, deliciously-flavored tomato sauce.

Their margherita pizza is pure perfection. I gotta try their other pizzas next time..

No really, there's no need to try any other pizza. This place wins.


*Drops mic, walks off stage*
author: Kazu O.

description:
I'm a big fan of Del Popolo - their 30,000 shipping container turned pizza kitchen full of nice people who are friendly to vegans make it worth my while to hike over to StreatFood every week or two for pizza.  John is very friendly and flexible when it comes to throwing together a vegan pie and the crust they make is DELICIOUS!

I'm totally hooked!

In the future, I'd love to see Del Popolo at the end of half marathon events in the vendor village area -- I'd pay for their pizza over eating the free bagels, peanut butter, bananas and frosted cupcakes served race finishers at some events.
author: Jenn C.

description: This review is about the service I've received from Del Popolo's events team. I've been in the process of trying to book Del Popolo's truck for an event in June. I reached out back in October and got a quick response with an estimate and was told I had a soft hold placed on the date I wanted. Understood, I reached out super early, makes sense they don't book that far out. Fast forward, its the end of January and I've emailed them numerous times about following up on the soft hold (as I was told January is when we could move forward) and got one response asking for the location of my event (when it was clearly in the email thread below) and that was the end of the communications. I sent 3 follow up emails and even went as far as reaching out to 2 other email addresses I found on their website and have left a voicemail with still no response. I really wanted to like Del Popolo, but this is just crappy service on their events team's part. If I could give them no stars I would.
author: Nicolette U.

description:
Hands down the best food truck I've ever patronized.  If you can find the truck (I highly recommend hunting it down!) don't be scared of the long line.  It is soooooo worth the wait, which really isn't even that long.  It just seems longer when you can't stop drooling over everyone else's pizza around you.   

Food:  We ordered the margherita and the sausage.  Both delicious but marg takes the cake for sure.  Perfectly cooked crust and fresh ingredients.  It doesn't get better than this, folks.   

Service:  Super friendly.  No complaints here.    

I wish we had a pizza food truck like this in Chicago.  So very very jealous!
author: A. M.

description:
Del Popolo is a wood fired oven on 4 wheels. The promise of quick good pizza is what lured me there originally; unfortunately the execution did not stack up to the theory.

The pluses included a short line during lunch time in SOMA and fresh ingredients. The minuses were small size, a fairly high price point and a terribly under-done crust. The first two points are forgivable but the third one is a deal-breaker. Why would one buy wood fired pizza if not for the crust?

Given how many pizza places are in this city I would suggest saving your time and going elsewhere for a proper pie.
author: Balaji V.

description: I keep going back and I think the pizza and organization of Del Popolo keeps getting better and better.  They are up to 4 regular selections from the 2 they featured the first time I visited last summer. My favorite is still their white pizza, but their margherita is great and their pepperoni is awesome as well.  Beyond that- I have endured a few lengthy waits in the past, in particular at their Mint plaza location, however I think they have made strides in their processes to move the line more quickly and get the pizzas in the customers hands faster.  Kudos for that!  Del Popolo remains one of my top 5 food truck selections and one of my top 5 pizzas, mobile or otherwise...
author: Andy S.

description: My pizza was burnt and tasteless such a shame cause I wanted to try this place for so long and was hoping it would be as great as the reviews but I was wrong it was such a waste of $12.50! :-(
author: Rita A.

description: The wait was over 30minutes to get this pizza but it was worth it! The crust was doughy but not under cooked and the edges were crispy. The cheese was delicious! We finished our two pizzas in about 3minutes! I would definitely love to check out the restaurant!
author: Nia R.

description:
One of the best food trucks in SF, plus one of the best pizzas in the city. If you like Flour & Water, Pizzeria Deflina style pizzas, you will like this one.

I've had both the margherita pizza & white pizza and they were both delicious. I couldn't try any other ones since they were sold out, but I will be hunting the truck down in the city because I love the pizza. The ingredients are fresh, the cheese is not overpowering, and the crust is chewy and sourdough-like (similar to Flour & Water - not surprising since the owner used to work there)

I don't think it's too pricey for the quality of pizza and type of pizza that you're getting. It's exactly what I'm always craving without the 2+ hour wait of going to Flour + Water.
author: Christina L.

description: I grew up in NY surrounded by mom and pop pizza places and lived in Italy for six months and pizza is my favorite food so I am always in search of great pizza and also picky. We read the great reviews and so my husband and I decided to try this place during a weekend we were in SF for our anniversary. We made relatively early reservations on a Friday night and by 6pm it was pretty packed.  The wait staff could not have been nicer. I ordered a beet salad with arugula and my husband had a mixed salad.  Both tasted great and nice sized portions. I had the margarita pizza and my husband had sausage. Sometimes with thin pizza I ask that it be extra crispy and I forgot but no worries it was cooked perfectly. My husband and I can both eat a lot of pizza but we ended up taking a little for a doggy bag. Pizza was great, cooked perfectly, nice size portion and tasty toppings. Nice wine selection too. We will be back.
author: renee m.

description:
Amazing!

Great quality pizza that comes out of a food truck!!!  Found this place after it was listed on the New York Times' #2 of the 50 Best Pizza places in the US.  And they are worth the title. 

We tracked all the way over 6-7 city blocks to get this and we would do it again! The pies are fresh as they get.  And they come out quick too.  About 5-6 mins straight after you order, they'll have the pie ready for you. 

We ordered all 3, bianca, margherita and the potato one.  All 3 were delicious.  They are a good sized pizza each enough to feed one person to the fullest.  You'll probably feel full after the 3rd slice, but you would want to finish the pie, because its that good.  

Also just to note, it comes out on a little metal flat plate that you can eat from nearby, but if you want to take it away its an extra 50c for the box.  But you don't want that anyways, it will be better fresh from the oven.  So do the environment a favor and just stuff your face.
author: Maggie F.

description:
Del Popolo stands out in the crowd like a 7 foot 2 inch rugby player that just so happens to be sporting a faux hawk. The reportedly $180,000 food truck carries rugged beauty within it's industrial design. You can actual see three people making the pizza from the dough to dressing to baking. The pizza oven is an unavoidable attraction as well. It feels a bit Wizard of Oz-ish to boot.

When we visited they offered two kinds of pizzas, margherita and meat. The meat offering was bit strange because they had pepperoni and spicy sausage on the menu but it seems like they only give you one kind of meat depending on how they're making.

The pizza has a very appetizing look to it. With the steaming pizza cloud billowing off the melted cheese, and the pillowy puffiness of the dough; this is a great looking pizza. The approximately 10-inch personal pizza is cut into quarters. I ate one myself but you could easily split this between two people.

Some people are saying that this pizza is undercooked, doughy, and "almost like naan bread" -- to certain extent they're right. The pizza has a great look but the peaks and edges of the pizza have torched burnt edges. The second thing you'll notice is that the pizza is surprisingly limp and without crisp. It's as if the dough was given enough time to pillow up but not actually cook through.

But does it taste good? Yeah it still tastes good. The dough, basil, and golden baked pepperoni taste great. The only thing that goes strange is the dough. You're expecting something crispy, light, and just slightly raw; yet, this goes too raw. I think the only reason this place is getting the amazing reviews is because it's straight out of the oven. I bet if you let the pizza sit for about fifteen minutes, you'll think this pizza wasn't that good.

____

Amazing truck and good flavors. I just hope they work on the cooking technique. The dough is just too goopy.

Note: Huge stomach ache afterwards. Grease or dough? I dunno which.
author: Michael H.

description:
Went back to this amazing truck this past Friday with a friend from out of town, and I was blown away YET AGAIN with how delicious the pizza was. 

They really have their act together with extremely warm & friendly service and such speediness--I got my pie less than 5 minutes from ordering! So amazed :).

The sauce on their pizza pies tastes SOOOO fresh and deliciously tomato-y. I'm convinced these guys use really special tomatoes or know some secret that nobody else knows.

Go try this truck ASAP--it should be on every San Franciscan's list!
author: Neeharika B.

description: Mad props for getting a giant wood burning oven into a food truck. Looks like they just launched the business so they only had one pizza on their "beta" menu. Fortunately their margherita was as solid as the shipping container they're cooking in. Very creative use of space and the giant glass panes allow you to peer inside. The folks hard at work seemed really friendly too.
author: Jeremy S.

description: One fine summer afternoon, I went for a pizza off the grid.  In the Presidio of San Francisco I found Del Popolo.  The idea here is you throw an 850°F oven into a container truck to make some sort of tactical support pizza vehicle.  Amazing! The line was super long but I decided to wait anyways.  The people were really friendly and the wait was surpisingly quick.  And the pizzas were delicious (had the margarita and the bianca).  Both perfectly cooked.  Lightly charred on the edges from the oven.  So good!
author: David S.

description:
RE: Margherita Pizza
The crust was awesome.
The sauce was like the runny, flavorless ketchup they try to pass for sauce in a can south of the border.

This flavorless, cheeseless atrocity can be yours for the low, low price of 12!
author: Angela P.

description:
This has to be the most innovative food truck I've seen - they have an actual wood burning fire inside.  The truck itself is beautiful; really awesome design.

The pizza, however, was just okay.  My coworker and I shared the meat one (wild boar salami) and the margherita. They were both good, nothing amazing.  At $15 for the meat one, I would have expected more - there was hardly any salami on the pizza. Both pizzas were really salty as well.  I think if they were a little less $$ I would have liked them better. 

They do take credit card, which is always a plus in my book!
author: Janine K.

description: I'm a TOTAL East Coast pizza snob. I've lived in San Francisco for almost 9 years, and this is the best pizza I've had in the city. Gorgeous truck, great service.
author: X-topher B.

description:
Not usually a fan of margherita pizzas, but maybe it's because I haven't had a good one before.  This truck is awesome - c'mon... wood burning oven in a truck?!  Winner!

Stopped by for lunch, probably took about 10 minutes to make once you ordered (lost track of time because we went to get ice cream at another truck during the wait), and I couldn't be happier.  The pizza was perfect.  One size, cut into four slices, $11.  Wasn't sure if we could finish it so + $0.50 for a container (not needed, we finished it).

Loved the margherita pizza and this was a great place to get it.  Adding this to my food truck stalk list.  Hope this comes by to the South Bay more often!
author: K P.

description: The best pizza in the Bay Area is actually from a truck. It is a shipping container fitted with a wood burning oven that cooks the crust hot enough to get a blistered, crispy consistency that is found usually only in the fanciest of pizza joints. Small personal size is enough for one. Find them at OTG, festivals like Outside Lands, or at selected curb sides. A perfect crust means a perfect pie, wait in line, you will not be sorry.
author: Kevin S.

description: Excellent pizza, excellent service and excellent dessert! Would recommend highly!! Especially loved the eclectic portraits on the walls. Very intimate and ambiance is nice.
author: Carly M.

description:
In the ever-expanding metropolis of food trucks, Del Popolo's novelty literally and figuratively towers above the rest.  The shipping container turned portable pizza exporter is instantly distinguishable at gatherings by its hulking stature and piercing aroma.  

The MEAT pizza conscripts daintily bitter rapini, slivers of potently spicy salami, and oases of melted fresh mozzarella to conquer any remnant of doubting taste buds.  Each satisfactory bite provides further evidence that this perfect storm of flavors is the result of rare artistry.  

However, an unmet expectation created by the anticipation of a crispy thin crust that wood-fire stoves are capable of delivering is manifested in the soft, doughy, and slightly charred foundation of Del Popolo pies.  Despite this confounding lack of support, each flimsy slice is still thoroughly enjoyable (but more like a taco!).
author: Andrew M.

description:
their long lines always turned me off bc i didn't want to wait whenever i saw them at osl or wherever they are.. finally decided to wait for them at off the grid: presidio.. if you're at off the grid, grab something else to tide you over while waiting in line like we did.. we picked up 2 pizzas to share with our small group.. loved their pizzas but wished some of the edges weren't so burnt.. 

can't wait for their brick and mortar to open up.. it'll only be down the block from my friends place in nob hill!
author: Raquel T.

description:
I knew I would like Del Popolo, as they're from the same creators of Flour and Water (also similar to Cupola, Mozzeria...). I would prefer being able to order by the slice, because it would maybe move the line faster.

In terms of the pizza itself, the dough as expected was perfectly chewy and amazing but it needed salt. The toppings were generous, so much more than Beretta and Delfina! But the salt from the pancetta and whatever else was on it, was overwhelming - between the dough and the toppings, they need to find a better salt balance.

The bottom line: Visit Popolo for the Pancetta if there is no line, otherwise skip it.
author: Jess C.

description:
i had the margherita with wild mushrooms added. 

the pizza was perfectly cooked with just the right amount of chew to the dough and char to pizza. 

i can honestly say that the truck itself was  pretty dope!!! not your average "food truck"...hahaha.

definitely worth the wait for a great bite at lunch time!
author: Donald G.

description: Good place for pizza and beers! Also the dessert was unbeliable!Awesome, attentive  and fast service. I love this place! I wish it would be cheaper. Good opcion for a romantic dinner!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Mobilizing a giant wood burning pizza oven is a feat. So is making amazing pizza. Sometimes you just eat something and wonder where it's been all your life. Welcome to Del Popolo.

Del Popolo catered a company lunch and it was incredible. I tried a slice from each of their pizzas and fell in love. They offer gluten free options too.
author: Andrew H.

description: Great margherita pizza compared to others I've had in San Francisco-definitely a must try.
author: Amir G.

description:
Neapolitan Pizza is currently my favorite type of pizza and I've been on a hunt to try as  many as I could. I was searching on Yelp and came across this food truck that has a brick oven built into it. Because its a huge brick oven, it is not your normal sized food truck but an taller & wider version.

I'm lucky enough to work a few blocks away from the Mint Plaza where they are located on Wednesday typically but I would always check their website/twitter feed to confirm before heading out.

They only offer a few different pies but I went with a friend so we shared half a Margarita and half a Bianca. The Margarita was out of this world but for me, a good sign of a Neapolitan Pizza is actually the dough. It has to have the nice uneven black crisps around the edge but also have a good chewiness to the texture. Their dough was on point and I thought better than Tony's in North Beach( to each their own). You also have the option to add meat to the Margarita, but then it wouldn't be a Margarita anymore.

Food Highlight: Margarita Pizza, Outdoor Seating if weather permits
author: Rich L.

description: Caught the reportedly $180k pizza truck at Outside Lands before the crowd arrived and was pretty pleased with my pie. Nice soft and chewy dough, sweet sauce and fresh tasting cheese. $12 seems kinda high but one is really kinda big for one person so maybe splitting 2 with three people gets you to $8 each which feels more ok.
author: Misha T.

description:
Today a couple of friends from work suggested we go to Del Popolo for lunch. It was described to me as a shipping crate converted into a pizza oven. The novelty alone and my love for Pizza was enough to get me to tag along. I'm very glad I did. 

The aesthetic of the truck was immediately arresting. The giant glass panes allowed us to watch as the pizza was made. The service was good and the wait was about 5-10. Not long but not especially short. The wait however, was completely worth it. The pizza I got (The Special with Salami) was easily one of the best Pizza's I've ever had. I cant strongly recommend you check this place out enough.
author: Mike R.

description: Glad to have this new snazzy restaurant in my 'hood. Nice beer and wine selections. We had the margarita pizza and the dough was tasty... a tad less salty than I like. Very fresh. Love that they have ice cream from Mr & Mrs Miscellaneous... it was fantastic as always. Also had the chocolate pot du creme; and that was good too. The interior is very nice; complete transformation from the previous tenants... now pizza is the show! Music was a bit loud; but we'll try it out again and see where it goes.
author: Micah K.

description: Maybe I'm missing something, but I thought this place was okay. I ordered the margherita. It was good, definitely not gross. I just feel like I've had better.  I'm kind of disappointed considering the fact that some people on Yelp say it's the best pizza in the city. I don't really like to give anything the title of "best in the city", because I know I haven't tried everything. I think these type of statements are just too bold. What I do know is that I really like the fresh spinach and shaved parmesan at Tommaso's. I wouldn't say that all Tommaso's pizzas are good, but I do know the fresh spinach and shaved parmesan pizza makes my tastebuds and my tummy oh so happy.
author: April D.

description:
Was not bad and was not great. I have definitely had way better at a better price. I probably would not go back considering the high price and bland taste. 

Service could use improvement for the guy taking orders comes off as being cocky.
author: Nyla S.

description: I eat at the Potrero hill location every Tuesday I can, since I work down the street. This pizza is so delicious! Mondays at work are so much worse because I have to wait a whole day to eat their pizza.
author: Roxanne G.

description: Not a hater. I don't like giving "bad" reviews as a three stars would let on. However, when you charge 14 bucks for a pizza and have a food truck the size of an SF apartment building I was expecting to be really wowed. I guess that's kind of the SF rub. We Bay Area folks really are a spoiled lot. I was expecting to get my pizza doors blown off. But, alas it was just "pretty good" today's special was a sausage pie with a chili oil drizzle. The line was about 35 mins long at Off the Grid in the Presidio. Sadly, I counted 6 sausages roughly the size of a quarter on my pie. Tons of amazing pizza in the city. Alas in the end I'm just nonplussed. Awesome truck though. I think that's what you pay for. The "show" of a two story truck and a "fancy" wood oven. Meh...
author: Johnathan D.

description: Completely blown again.  Probably the best pizza I've ever had.  Seriously there is absolutely nothing wrong with their pizza that can be improved upon.  Love that you can seriously taste each of the ingredients.  The dough is amazing, great texture, not too burnt, and just the right amount of chewiness.  Can't wait to go back and try more flavors!  Seriously I can eat this every day!
author: Tiffany C.

description: First time having a Margherita pizza, loved it! Awesome that they have a wood burning oven in their truck! Makes the pizza taste more authentic! Perfect amount of sauce cheese and basil on a thin crispy crust. For what you get it's a little pricey but well worth it $11 gets you the cheese pizza and for $3 more you can add meat. If you're debating whether or not to wait in line to order from this food truck... do it! Well worth it!
author: Alisha W.

description:
I would love to give this a 4.5 star rating because it's really good.  The tomato sauce is delicious - it smells and tastes like it's truly garden fresh.  

Quality crust, if a little too burnt, and the portions are just about right.  I'd like to see some optional fresh parmesan to top it with, and perhaps a bit better beverage selection.  

Overall, super yummy and worth the price to treat yourself.
author: Matt N.

description:
Pizza on wheelz!
Good pizza at that. Del Popolo is the pizza truck with a pizza oven in it; it's pretty cool.
I had a margarita style with an orange fanta and felt like i was 12 but with better pizza. There was a crispy yet soft crust and a good sauce with a just amount of cheese. There were some carcinogens present but I didn't mind that too much. It was a solid pizza that I would eat again but it didn't blow me away, didn't open my eyes to the true light.
Yes, Enjoyable.

The down side has nothing to do with Del Popolo. The down side was the line which was a longer wait than the time it took to cook the pizza. Additionally the people in live all talked way to loud. Some things are private and some things are boring and somethings are just not worth shouting about. Also if I ever get stuck in live behind the guy I was in line this time(looked like he was trying to be both Black Keys all at once) I will shove him. His name's Phil, shove him if you see him and tell him his girlfriend's an ugly shrew.
maybe I hate lines. I don't hold the pizza people responsible for this though, they got buzz and they got popularity.
author: Alexander R.

description:
Yum. YUHH-HUMMMM.

Did you catch that? The pizza is incredibly yum. 

A friend of mine had bought the #1 (tomato, fresh mozzarella, basil, extra virgin olive oil, and sea salt) and the #2 (fresh mozzarella, ricotta, grana padano, basil, and garlic), split them in half, and gave me half of each.

I walk into work and find a pizza box sitting on my desk. (One must never question a good thing.) I open it and begin to devour, not questioning why it's there, how it got there, if it's even safe to eat--I -just kept chewing and drooling because it was just so damned good. 

Nay! It was GLORIOUS. Like songbirds-chirping-alongside-my-window-and-unicorns-pooping-rainbows glorious. I enjoyed the #1 one better than the #2 (tee hee), but my friend had the opposite taste; different strokes, I suppose. And for $10-$11 for a delicious, personal, wood-fired pizza, it's a steal!
author: Adena B.

description:
A nice surprise!  Caught them at SoMa Streatfood.  They were offering three pizzas (pies only, no slices!): margherita (mozzarella and tomato sauce), bianca (with ricotta, basil, garlic, and some heat), and "meat" (which had some other toppings).  Notes!
- We got margherita and bianca.  Both were great, but the bianca was the surprise winner for me: much more flavor despite lacking tomato sauce.  We all agreed we liked the variety and preferred to get tastes of both.
- The awesomest thing was definitely the crust.  It's technically thin crust, but it was unique among pizzas I've had: a little gooey on the inside (like almost undercooked) but deliciously toasty (as in small parts were dark brown) on the outside.  Not sure if they only placed pizzas in the over when ordered... if so, they cook damn fast.  If not, the place is a little slow! :)
- We got two pizzas to split between three of us, all modestly above average sized guys.  It was the perfect amount.  So get a takeaway box if you order a pizza solo, but don't try to share one pizza between two people either.
- Oh right, it's the coolest looking truck ever.  Like a post modernist industrial loft on wheels.  Too bad I can't live in it.
author: Aaron M.

description: I have been experiencing withdrawals over the holidays with no pizza from del Popolo.  Both the white and the red are thrilling - I have to take someone with me to split them, it is like Sophie's Choice trying to choose.
author: Robert M.

description:
Only a few years ago "roach coaches","taco carts", and "sandwich trucks" were scary but were often also the only cheap lunch alternative for construction workers and other workers with short lunch breaks, small paychecks, and limited lunch options.

They served an important niche,rolling up to underserved workplaces, but offered only mass produced cheap high fat and unhealthy food.

Then some LA truck switched out packaged high calorie premade sandwiches and burritos for a healthy gourmet menu. Seemingly overnight the "roach coach" morphed into the "food truck", parked in nicer neighborhoods, and became a major source of cutting-edge cuisine in hip foodie cities for discerning consumers.

They did, however, continue to reproduce like roaches.  

Slider, BBQ, and ethnic-with-a-twist ("street food +") trucks painted with a catchy graphic on a converted step van multiplied like mushrooms in an Oregon cow pasture after a rainstorm.
 
City laws forced the trucks to park randomly rather than in a dependable location. Devotees had to twitter and tweet ,if they were lucky, to locate their favorite truck each day.

Clearly someone needed to provide a  permanent space where these cutting edge mobile restaurateurs could gather and prosper and be compared.  

Somebody did.  Thanks.  In San Francisco it's called SOMASTREATFOODPARK. I found a stunning new gem there recently in the Del Popolo truck.

This split-level steam-punk styled truck is turning out perfect Neopolitan thin-crust pizzas. Yes, "split-level"!  The 20' oceanic shipping container that some twisted and brilliant designer converted into a mobile kitchen towed behind a semi has side-to-side, floor-to-ceiling removable glass doors/windows, framed by Jules Verne style metal.  All while affording a complete view of the making of your pizza.

You may need to read that again, but you won't really appreciate it until you see it.  At customer level in the front they take your order and deliver the pizzas from (believe it or not) A REAL ITALIAN-MADE WOOD-FIRED PIZZA OVEN! 

SERIOUSLY.  IN A TRUCK.

Half a human higher behind them in the rear of the kitchen are the guys that actually crank out the pies.  Oh sure, they could have been on the same level as the server.  Anyone else on foodtruck earth would have been happy to do that. But then you couldn't see them strut their pizza stuff. And these guys have LOTS of pizza stuff to strut.

I am so much more impressed when I am served a simple perfect thing than I am when I am sold a complicated pretentious failure.  The latter is too common.  Even in food trucks (see Fish Truck review).

Del Popolo has only 4 pizzas (3 when I was there, no potato).  They are done perfectly so there is no need for anything else.  

Here is their menu:     http://www.delpopolosf.com/about.php#menu

You won't need or want anything else.  Except maybe a beer or sangria at another booth if you are at SOMA STREATFOOD PARK.

http://somastreatfoodpark.com/


All hail Del Popolo!  What "roach coach" was to become "food truck",  Del Popolo will be to what "food truck" will (has?) become. Eat here now and take a giant step into the future of mobile dining.  And, oh yeah, have a damn good meal.  Ha.
Very well done indeed.
author: Gary N.

description:
Thank you, Del Popolo, for providing me with a delicious pizza!!!!  After my recent pizza disaster (see Patxi's reviews), I needed a good pick-me-up.  And you delivered in spades.

Every once-in-a-while, Del Popolo pops up behind Williams Sonoma's office for lunch.  This is my second time having the Margherita pizza, both times being equally amazing.  The dough seemed like it melted in my mouth, yet it was still chewy.  The smoky taste from the bits of charred dough gave it an authentic flavor.  The sauce was just right - fresh tasting and not too sweet.  Add to it the perfect amount of cheese and basil, and voila!  A yummy pizza pie.

No, this isn't a New York pizza.  But it is a great alternative.

Eat.From.This.Truck.
author: Larry Z.

description:
This truck is parked outside of SFMoMA on Thursdays (not sure if it's going to change location since SFMoMA is closing for a couple of years) but the line was ridiculous. Ridiculous in a good way. It was long but it kept moving. We were staring at the menu unsure if we wanted to try it but then this lady who just got her pizza was like "get the bianca, we come every thursday to get it. it's SO good!". 

So I cave to peer pressure or just a "OMG IT'S SO GOOD" recommendation easily. Bianca it is! My coworker wanted to try the meat too so we got both and split it. 

The first bite into the Bianca was like creamy heaven. It's a pizza with Fresh mozzarella, fresh ricotta, basil, garlic, extra virgin olive oil. It was PIPING hot because they have a freaking wood fire oven IN the truck! Granted there were a little crispy burnt spots on the pizza, it had a nice smoky flavor to it. 

The Meat, on the other hand (Fresh mozzarella, Yukon Gold potatoes, pancetta, rosemary), was good but not "omg it's so good!" good. This pizza was decent. It was salted which was a little odd to me, but I'm a fan of salt so I was ok with it. It was a ... "why does this taste like there's salt, oh wait, there is salt on this? huh? i guess it works?". I didn't think it was worth the $14. 

The Bianca is priced at $12 which is still a tad high for food truck, thin crust pizza but I'll gladly fork over the money to put this in my belly.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Wait, this pizza was from a what?? A truck? Yep. You've got that right. Some of the best pizza I've had in a long time. Rivals Delfina and Tony's. I had the Margarita pizza  which had the best amount of sauce, basil, and mozzarealla. Simple but delicious. All pizzas are cooked in a wood burning oven which gives it that great flavor. I'll definitely be stalking this truck for lunch. 

Make sure you come early, the line builds up quick.
author: Sarah T.

description: neat looking food truck that produce top notch pizza!
author: Long C.

description:
We ordered the Bianca, which had ricotta mozzarella garlic basil, and loved it the best.

We also ordered the Margherita, with Tomato mozzarella  garlic and basil and it was okay....

We went at about  11:45 am today and they are pretty fast and the line is not too long.

Heads up, if you get it to go, you have to pay for the box.

The burnt edges of the crust is not our favorite flavor but the crust itself for the pizza is very nice and thin.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Had to update review: Recently we hired Del Popolo to cater an event for us, yes they cater! Let's just say this is "the ultimate pizza delivery". Same amazing pizza, but made fresh at our front door :) Our guests were so excited and had such a great time not only eating the pizza but also watching John and his brother hard at work.  In addition to the 2 pizzas they normally make, margherita and white, they added a combo pizza with broccoli rabe and type of salami. 

Del Popolo truly "delivered" Can't wait to get them for another event!
author: Eugene P.

description: I am obsessed!   I love it when Del Popolo is in Potrero on Tuesdays - I am there pretty much every week with my coworkers.  The Bianca pizza is perfection and their seasonal specials are amazing.  I am also super impressed that these guys remember the names and orders of so many people just by sight.  They are opening a brick & mortar store in Nob Hill which I am SO excited about!
author: Joyce W.

description:
Solid pizza. I went with high expectations since it made the top 101 pizza list in the US. The ingredients were extremely fresh, the dough was cooked perfectly, and the people were great!

It did not disappoint. There is something to be said about pure, simple ingredients. This is the pizza Italians would be proud of. Even though it was cooked perfectly with the exact sauce to cheese ratio that warrants it's reputation as a top pie, it didn't blow my socks off. Great quality and would go back, but in this world of competitive pizza making, I wouldn't say it's the best pizza I've ever had. I would give it a 4.5 if I could. Must try for yourself!
author: Shirley S.

description:
We tried ghe Margherita pizza at Off the Grid. It was slightly burnt, very thin layer of cheese, what seemed liked canned tomato sauce which was very runny, and what seemed like two leaves of basil.

Very expensive fare for sub par pizza.
author: Andy r.

description:
So, so happy that there is such a fabulous truck roaming the streets of San Francisco! The design of this truck seriously puts the others to shame. It is a living, fire-breathing, pizza-delivering beast!

I ordered the margherita, which was very fresh - as fresh as a pizza could be - just the right blend of tomatoes, basil, and cheese. It was yummy, but def. not up to Delfina's. But the cardboard box did not soak through with nasty oil like other pizzerias. Although $11 was a little steep for the little round in my box, it was tasty and half of it sufficed for a noon-time meal.

You can see the workers making the pizza through the large windows on one side of the truck, and it looks so clean, bright, and yes, SPACIOUS! I loved watching their little assembly line. And the wood burning oven INSIDE the truck is no joke!

I would definitely recommend this if you haven't tried it yet. If not for the pizza, then most assuredly to take a photo with the truck!
author: Jen L.

description:
It's like the stereotypical 'prettiest girl in school', she knows it and has nothing really else to offer.

Wow, pretty awful service.  I don't even care how good the pizza is, it'll end up tasting bitter once you get it.  I made the unfortunate mistake of complementing the truck and engaging in (very) small talk while my card was being processed, my mistake.  You're really not that cool.

I'm split on giving it one or two stars.
author: Justin L.

description:
I had the Del Popolo pizza when the truck was set up for dinner at Bar Agricole (Mondays). The heated patio with outside bar is a lovely place to enjoy the wood-fired pizza.

I shared the margherita pizza and the white pizza (ricotta and garlic i think) and both were cooked well with a pleasantly charred thin crust. I enjoyed the white pizza more than the margherita because it was a bit more flavorful. I couldn't pick up as much flavor as I would have liked from the tomato sauce on the margherita but the cheese and basil were great. There was another pizza offered with a meat topping but that is the extent of what the pizza truck offers. The pizzas are personal sized so don't expect to have leftovers if you order one per person but that amount does the trick for a regular meal. I was at the truck on the earlier side of the evening so the wait was minimal and they were able to take the time execute the pizzas well.

At $10 a pop the pizzas are reasonably priced. It looks like the prices have been consistently creeping up so I am very curious to see where they land, especially considering this is food truck dining lacking the ambiance and service of a brick and mortar establishment (most of the time).

I will probably revisit the truck but only at this location or another like it. It really is the combination of the solid pizza, with the access to great cocktails and an awesome patio that made this meal stand out. San Francisco has plenty of excellent pizza offerings these days.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
This the most grand food truck I've ever seen. Almost all food trucks tend to be roach coaches painted in glamorous colors or has super cool add ons such as tvs, stone ovens, etc., but this food truck is actually a truck! They basically converted a rather large delivery truck into a pizza baking factory! This thing is pretty huge, so you won't ever miss it. It also has a big built in oven to bake the pizza. 

Apparently this truck has been roaming around SOMA for a little bit now. It came within walking distance from the financial district, so I decided to give it a try. 

They usually have 3 kinds of pizza, a margherita, Bianca (white) and meat. My coworker and I split a margherita and a bianca. It took less than 10 minutes for the pizza to come out. I was actually surprised because reading up the reviews for other pizza food trucks, people complained about how long their pizza took to bake. It didn't take that long!

They try to encourage you to eat it right there since they serve it on a metal pizza sheet, and I advise you to eat it when you get it! This thin crust pizza is cooked to perfection! It was cooked just right! Gooey, but it was cooked enough for the pizza to not fall apart in your hands. The ingredients were fresh and tasty, the prices were reasonable, and the truck was just so cool! What else can you ask for?!

When you spot this truck, this is a MUST try!
author: Ayaka S.

description:
I got really excited when I saw this truck pull up behind me in the Mint plaza, while I was waiting in line for Blue Bottle.  Alas, I was really, really disappointed. 

Here's the thing: the truck is really cool.  It's very well designed, it has an awesome oven, and the pizzas go from a ball of freshly made and tossed dough to steaming hot pie in under a minute.  Very impressive for something on wheels.  No surprise the line was 30+ people long.

The pizzas they're making, though... they just aren't very good.  

To be fair, I had one.  Once.  I ordered the margarita pizza.  It was bland and undercooked.  The oven is so hot that the crust chars and bubbles on the edge/top, but aside from that, it's squishy and spongy.  I guess some people like pizza like that, but I don't.  It was more like naan bread than anything else, and utterly flavorless.  When you're throwing away your edge crust instead of stealing other people's, you know you aren't eating good pizza.

The sauce was bland.  It didn't taste like good tomatos, it wasn't too sweet or salty, it was just... bland.  The mozzarella they use had no bite, didn't taste like much at all.  Honestly, the only thing I could really taste on the pizza was the basil.  Everything else was pretty much just spongy, chewy, doughy matter in my mouth. 

I didn't try the white pizza (white sauce, garlic, ricotta cheese, some other stuff), so that might be better.  But ultimately, my first impression of this truck is that it's all sizzle, and no steak.  

I might go back if they're near my office again, but I will do so knowing that I might have to buy a second lunch later in the day.
author: Jace P.

description: Love love el-u-vee the new spot. Been waiting for this pizzaiolo to set up permanent shop for years. Glad he has his own space. If you missed him at Flour and Water, check him out now on bush. Or at the truck. (Yelp should separate out these reviews, me thinks)
author: Chris A.

description: Stopped by Del Popolo at the Soma Street Food Truck Park. The line was already huge by the time I arrived but I had been wanting to try it so I decided to wait. I ordered the Margarita pizza. About 30 minutes later I was finally able to eat! The pizza was good, crust was thin and cooked all the way through. There were some burnt bubbles on the crust, which was kind of a bummer. But overall it was a good pie.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Decent Margherita not ultra thin, not soggy, charred,flavor was good, big edge was chewy.

Una Pizza Napoletana and Tonys still rule SF
author: Ellen H.

description: Waited in line for 45 minutes at Off the Grid In the Presidio for this pizza and it was worth it! I stuck to the basics and enjoyed a fantastic tomato sauce, mozzarella and basil on a fluffy, crunchy and tasty crust. I will definitely be eating this pizza again.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I give them props for having an awesome truck!

I had the margarita pizza which was pretty good, though nothing mind blowing. Also the crust is really thin and the pizza just isn't that big so I was definitely still hungry afterwards.

Maybe next time I will try the other pizza and add the meat (though that would make it $14)...
author: Ely L.

description:
This is an amazing pizza, from a truck no less. I wish I could give it a 4.5. If I didn't have the memory of Apizza Scholls in PDX to compare it to, this would be a 5 stars.

It's in the top 3, behind Apizza Scholls in Portland, OR and Backspace in Austin, TX.  Pretty amazing from a pretty amazing truck!
author: Ben T.

description:
Best pizza in America?!

The pie looks ok (we had a Margherita and a Bianca), but the tomato sauce on the Margherita was terrible. The Bianca wasn't particularly tasty either.

Stick to Cheeseboard for seriously good pizza.
author: Chetan G.

description:
They make the simplest yet flavorful pizzas in San Francisco!

I first heard of them on an online lifestyle mag, I believe it was refinery29. What did strike my interest in Del Popolo is the concept of having a stone wood-kindled oven on a truck with a sense of transparency of how they make the gourmet pizza!

I was on my way to a meeting today after visiting Jeremy's in South Park. There was a crowd gathering in front of The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen with the Del Popolo truck; must be a Thirsty Thursday event! 

Took my chance of ordering their pizza despite the crowd! They had Margherita (tomato, basil, mozzarella) for $10, White Vegetarian (mozzarella, ricotta, basil, garlic) for $11, and Meat (pepperoni, onion, ripini, mozzarella, chili oil) for $14. Based on the ingredients, they definitely have a traditional Italian touch to them; so bliss.

My wait time for their pizza was worth the experience since you get to see all the action through the glass panes; it's definitely a crowd drawer for all ages. After the wait and commute to the meeting, I finally tasted the pizza I just bought. I'm definitely sold by it's simplicity and flavorful ingredients, especially the crust, definitely well done.

I'm very much looking forward to what Del Popolo is going to share, especially that the food truck concept they have is quite novel!

P.S. pardon the lengthy saga, I just had to make an awesome review for them :)
author: Pierre B.

description:
These guys make some seriously delicious pizzas. The bianca with pepporoni is the bomb. But the best part about it is the fact that the Del Popolo staff are super friendly and easy going... i watched a homeless man rifle through the trash can looking for some leftover pizzas.... The front of house staff member made the homeless man stop sifting through the trash and then gave him a fresh pizza straight out of the oven.... I was pretty stoked to see such a great act of generosity which speaks volumes about the kind of people that have made this place a bit of an institution! 

Nice work fellas. I'll be back again for sure!
author: El P.

description: Great thin crust pizza. The tomato sauce is delicious and the pizza margarita is awesome. We loved it!!
author: Haim M.

description:
Del Popolo is without question one of San Francisco's best food trucks. 

The menu is always small and to the point, with only a few simple but delicious options, using pretty fantastic ingredients. 

The truck itself appeals to those interested in design, and it's a far cry from the typical food truck roaming the streets. When you walk by, your bound to take a second look, and admire the beautiful glass front and wood fire pizza oven. 

While a bit pricey, I can't really complain when I'm sitting in Yerba Buena Gardens on a sunny day, eating the wonderful Fresh mozzarella, ricotta, and grana padano pizza. 

Truly delightful.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Quite a site to be seen at Outside Lands! I have read about and seen pictures of this creation, but it is truly amazing to see in person. You really can't describe it better than a wood fired pizza oven on a gigantic truck.

I may be slightly biased, as I always prefer thin crust, wood fired pizzas, but this was some good pizza! I was pretty close to sober when eating this too. There was a considerable line to wait in, but not at the fault of the owners. With as many people out as there were, I was not surprised to see the line grow much longer as the weekend carried on. As soon as I placed my order, the pizza was ready in less than three minutes. Crazy fast!

Anytime your pizza costs the same as your beer, $10, it better be some damn good pizza, since no single beer is worth $10 (see my review of Suppenküche for exceptions).
