We have some rather frequent food truck meet-ups here in Sac and we would love to have this truck come up and visit us! I would assume the profit wouldn't be enough to cover for the crazy gas bill though.
author: Chris B.

description:
Had a tasty pizza at Outside Lands; probably the best eats of the festival. 

They were very efficient; in line for 5 mins. Waited 3-4 mins for pizza. 

Magherita was tasty, crust was a little doughy and chewy but thin. For $10, the best deal.

Gorgeous truck too...like a really contemporary loft. I could live in it!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Del Popolo brings a whole new definition to the word food truck. It's a shipping container converted into a kitchen with a food fire oven inside and that shipping container is tightly secured onto a truck. Truly this blows the away any other food trucks in comparison. One side of the container has been ripped out and replaced by windows, which gives a really nice view of what's happening on the inside. It's amazing to see three people manning this place and spitting out a couple of pizzas every few minutes.

The Bianca pizza with meat was amazing! It's a small personal size pizza, but it size does not matter here! On second thought, more would've been good. Drool. The pizza dough was cooked to a soft, doughy, and chewy texture. The tomato sauce with garlic oil tasted pretty heavenly. The ricotta and mozzarella cheese made a perfect combo on top of the pizza. The peperoni was the only thing that didn't knock my socks off me... it tasted like peperoni.  

Overall, it's one really delicious tasting pizza, but it hurts the wallet so much. Bianca costs $12 and the meat costs $3. My advice is to skip the meat, which gives about 12 slices of pepperoni. If it was cheaper, this will definitely become my favorite lunch time haunt. However, it's too pricy for me to become a regular.
author: Steven B.

description: Great, fresh, amazing food and pizza. Staff was RUDE. I spent $700 for a team dinner and was unbelievably disappointed by how I was treated. They are very concerned with ensuring they appear busy and full at all times, which must be why they asked me and my party to leave the second we put our forks down stating they had "the next party waiting". They did not apologize or ask, we were basically kicked out.  I would avoid until there is a staff turnover...maybe try takeout?
author: Chelsea L.

description: Great pizza for SF gravity was there tomato sauce was perfect and the ratio of cheese on the margarita was excellent.  Perfect portion size for one person or as mini meal for two.  My only complaint mind you is lack of crispness of dough seemed a little chewy.    I'm from New York so I am spoiled when it come to pizza and like my thin crust quite crispy just a little overdone.  Which this was not but still excellent.  Flavor was all there.
author: Natalie K.

description:
So I finally got to try out the famous Del Popolo pizza trying to find out if it was famous for it's pizza or for the truck it's made in.  I think seeing the truck alone is worth the price of the pizza.  
On the day I went there were two varieties the margherita and the blanca (you guessed it, white) with options for pepperoni.  The pizzas are authentic Neapolitan style.  In a group we ordered each and even had one more margherita with the pepperoni.   The pizzas were baked perfectly and the dough was extraordinary.  The overall taste of the pizza's were very good.  The one disappointment was the pepperonis.  For an added $2 you get 4 slices per pizza's, which I wouldn't complain if they used some type of artisenal meat but this looked and tasted like your standard store bought pepperoni which is like putting Raghu on homemade pasta.
author: Joe G.

description:
cool truck.

pizza sucked.

took a freightliner  business class m2 and stuck a cargo container on the back and stuck in a wood burning oven, a cold storage station that doubles as a working counter and of course hand washing station to satisfy them heath codes. 

cool.

two points on the food and service. 

first and foremost, with a lineage the folks here have, the crust SHOULDNT be the way i got mines. neopolitan style pizza? not really.  lacked in taste as well. 

i can name a couple handful of places i prefer over this place. 

which leads me to the second point.

i dont care what your lineage is, even if you had great food, unfriendly, bad customer service still pushes people away. subpar food AND unfriendly staff? well, you dont have to take my word for it (and honestly you shouldnt, everyone should find out for themselves) but give it a try. 

maybe i should convert one of my frieghtliners and do the same thing... i did see a special deal on some used cargo containers.
author: Euge L.

description: My experience with Del Popolo was like an amazing one night stand. I had it at a party but never got their name. I've been fantasizing about it ever since and only when I saw Chow's pick of pizzas and the amazing accompanying photo did I realize the identity of that which had given me such pleasure. I will be stalking them.
author: Susie W.

description: My friend and I live in the neighborhood and wanted to check out this new restaurant and support the local business. Though a bit loud and crowded, the decor was nice and the atmosphere inviting. We both ordered a pizza; the margherita and the house sausage. When the two pizzas were delivered to our table, the waiter mistakingly forgot the toppings we requested and offered to redo it for us. When he brought it back not only were the sides of this pizza completely burnt, but also the first pizza (house sausage) was also burnt as well. Furthermore, both bottoms of the pizzas were almost completely black. When we told the waiter about this his only response was: "our ovens are at 1000 degrees, this is how we cook our pizza," and walked away without any further comments. This was just plain rude in my opinion. Now I understand that this is the style of pizza but the degree at which this pizza was burnt was completely unacceptable and is not how "this style" of pizza should be, or is even, cooked in a restaurant charging these prices. All in all, I am completely dissatisfied with the food and the service here and will not be returning and will be telling others of the poor service received at this failed attempt of an up-scale restaurant.
author: Alex G.

description: This pizza on wheels is the only thing that has that taste of Italy in the bay. The dough is very thin and the crust is just right. I got the traditional pizzeria and thought I  was in Italy!! I highly recommend this place to anyone coming up to the Bay Area for a nice weekend. Bravo Bravo!!
author: Harpua P.

description:
Hmmm..... Ooooh I get it, you have a cool looking truck but shouldn't the pizza be good too? In the immortal words of PE " don't believe the hype. " I have tried this truck on two different occasions and both times the edges of the pie was burned while the dough in the middle was badly undercooked. They also put way too much salt on top of the margherita pizza. I say go see the truck and eat at one of the better food trucks out there while doing it.

Pros =  cool looking truck
              Potential to be better if they try
Cons  = poorly cooked food
             
This is probably closer to two stars but both times I went the owners have this arrogant kinda I'm so cool vibe so I'm knocking it down. Your truck is cool, not you.
author: James S.

description:
You've seen a million food trucks (well in the bay area you have, at least...), but you've never seen anything like the mobile pizza cathedral that is Del Popolo. 

We hired them for our wedding at the Oakland Zoo, and wowed our guests, including a gourmet pizzaolo with what he described as, "some f#$%ing amazing za!"

Del Poplo gave us several pizzas to choose from, the staff was friendly and helpful, and the price was not to be beat! Quick, easy, and absolutely delicious. A hearty salute to the boys and girls of Del Popolo.
author: Johanna W.

description: I didn't like this pizza---and the burned bubbles, especially on the white pizza overwhelmed the taste of everything. It was also soggy in the middle . Inedible...
author: Anibel B.

description: Amazing crust, the tomato sauce was fresh and the mozzarella was excellent.  Easily ranks as one of my favorite pizzas.  Line was a bit long, but from order to pizza was super fast.
author: brad m.

description: I've tried to get Del Popolo pizza a few times but have never been lucky enough to reach the front of the line in time. Finally got my hands on two pizzas, one was the Bianca (which was SOOOO good!) and I can't remember the other. Due to the price, $12ish each, I figured that the pizzas would be really small - nope, one is definitely enough to share between two people. We ended up looking like fat kids at a buffet two whole pizzas plus other off the grid grub. Del Popolo is definitely worth the wait!
author: Gina C.

description: NASA fit a car into a rocket that landed on Mars: 5 Stars. Del Popolo fit a wood-burning pizza oven into a shipping container on a truck frame: 5 Stars. And, their pizza: 5 Stars. When it comes to wood burning, traditional pizza... it's on par with the rest of the city. And, it's out of a truck -- like at Outside Lands. Hoards of people, and "Number 95... Number 95..." flaked on his sausage pie. I pounced on that pie & they were thrilled about it. On a lazy workday lunch, or a sunny weekend or on a frigid park night, this pie coupled with a beer -- at a $1 an inch... is a true gift.
author: Jon A.

description:
its just a big fancy truck people. there's so many other places that have better pizza that isn't burnt....not blackened/cajun...BURNT! it's not worth it.

even AK Subs has a better open face french bread pizza sandwich.
author: Craig I.

description: I had just moved from NYC, so I was worried about where I was going to find a decent margherita pizza in the bay area. I saw the Del Popolo truck at one of the Off the Grid events, and decided to give it a shot. I didn't know what to expect since the pizza was being made in a truck and not a proper brick oven, but I was pleasantly surprised! The pies were small, but they tasted great and were made quite quickly.
author: Sean W.

description: So amazing and great, the service was outstanding and the food was fantastic, we had them serve at our Holiday party and it was a huge hit!!!
author: Meg G.

description: When my friend shared about this $180,000 food truck, I just had to check it out.  Plus - I really love pizza!  I must say that they make a very delicious wood-fire baked pizza.  I've tried their white pizza.  It was creamy delicious.  I really look forward to trying their other options.
author: Alvin J.

description: I finally got to try this at Soma Streatfood Park. The pizza was good, the margarita pizza was a little salty, but the Bianca pizza was delicious!
author: Miranda R.

description: Love the Bianca! I order 1 and take 1 or 2 to-go. Haven't seen them in awhile but need to hunt them down soon!
author: Vicki R.

description: This truck gets 4 stars purely for being beautiful.  The pizza is good, the ingredients great, but the crust a little undercooked.
author: beverly l.

description:
Cool truck.

I was a bit dissapointed as the crust is a bit too chewy for my taste.  I hear it's supposed to be like that so perhaps it's a preference thing.

I'd really prefer Delfina Pizza.
author: Andy W.

description: $14 for big salty floppy piece of Naan bread with a squirt of ragu on it.  Come On now fool. You tripping. Also.....  What's with your POS system? 2 fools in front of me wanted to split the pizza on their 2 cards. That created 10 mins of drama while the line built behind us and in the end they ran to an ATM to complete the transaction. What's with the cash register chick? That system of taking orders and giving out pizzas from the same window sucks. She gets confused easily and starts giving customers the eye roll when she gets flustered. I don't deal with $14 for burnt naan and the stink-eye to boot. DX that ho fo' someone with better flo'. You think you're flour and water, but everything points to dominos.
author: Mark B.

description: One would think by the looks of the woodfire it'll be crispy but it was not. A little too burnt tasting for me and soggy too. Would give 3 stars if it were about $7..
author: E T.

description: Okay so I have been patiently waiting to try this food truck's pizza.  I read an article from Thrillist about this man who decided to have a truck custom made with the fire wood oven in the truck and clear glass on one side.  It's a spectacular truck I might add.  So today, finally my wait ends.  I went to Mint Plaza in the city to order the Margarita Pizza.  They had a 150 pizzas to make and sale, that's it.  I got there just in time, before the crowd came in and there were already about 10 people waiting for their order.  They only make two pizzas the Margarita and something else.  I was torn the other pizza was White garlic cream but I played it safe and ordered the Margarita.  LOVED IT! The sauce was light, very tasty and there was a lot of flavor.  The pizza is very tasty, without a doubt.  So if you're in the city, tweet Del Popolo and find out where they are parked, they only make a certain amount of pizza pies.  I'm sure they go fast.  I will be looking for them in the future for real!  I love pizza, my all time favorite meal and Del Popolo rocks.
author: Liz D.

description:
I recently found out there are two major SF pizza trucks (that I know of): Casey's (review forthcoming) and this. And now that I've tried both, it's no contest: Del Popolo is far superior, offering a fantastic pie for a reasonable price. And even when you compare it to immobile pizza shops, it stacks up VERY favorably.

Pros: 
-Excellent pie (I had the marghertia) with tasty sauce, yummy chewy crust, fresh mozzarella, and a splash of olive oil. Despite coming off of a truck, it's in my San Francisco Top 5 Pizza Places. I'd say 1) Tony's. 2) Una Pizza Napoletana. 3) Pizzeria Delfina. 4) Gialina. 5) Del Popolo. Though I've got plenty of other places to try yet. :-)
-Good price. $11 for the marg. It's a tad smaller than a lot of the Neapolitan-style pizzas I've eaten, so I guess that makes it comparable to the $13 for a larger margherita at lots of my other favorite SF spots, but it's still enough for a "lunch pizza" and much, much more reasonably priced than Casey's, which is $17 (!) for the same pie.

Cons:
-My big issue -- and perhaps this was an isolated incident -- but we ordered 2 margs and a sausage. The two margs came out simultaneously, but the sausage was not the next pizza out of the oven. In fact, it was about an extra 10-minute wait. I'm not sure what their system is and if it was broken or working properly in this case, but I was annoyed because by the time I got to sit down and eat my marg it wasn't piping hot anymore.
-Cash only. This is more Yelp's problem than Del Popolo's, but be warned that this truck does NOT accept credit cards even though Yelp says it does. Maybe they do on other days (we went on Sunday to their Presidio location).
-This is a nitpick, but I could've done with a bit more cheese. Del Popolo's pie is a lot redder than it is white. Didn't stop it from being delicious, though.

Also, this isn't a con because you can't fault Del Popolo for its own success, but as others have noted, be prepared for a long line. It never let up the whole 2 hours we hung out on the Presidio grass near the Del Popolo truck. This isn't a place to stop for a quick bite to eat. Plan for that and you'll be fine.
author: Ryan M.

description: Fantastic pie and worth the wait.  Excellent service.
author: April M.

description: The pizza here is amazing! Lovely toppings on top of a crunchy, chewy and delicious crust.
author: O O.

description: As I frequent the new food truck park, SoMa StrEat Food, I have probably tried most food trucks in the city.  This is one notch I was missing on my belt.  Well, they were there the other night and even though I was ready to have one of my go to meals, I decided I couldn't pass up this opportunity.  I had been hanging out to eat from this truck since I read they were going to be opening.  They did not disappoint!  WOW, this is some seriously good pizza.  Great serving size, hot, crusty, tasty, I forgot that I had been hanging out for seafood.  Friendly service, and my dog loved being able to say hello which is a bonus.
author: D B.

description: If your one of the people that believe that "Food Heaven" actually exists, then you gatta trust me on this one. Now, I tried pizza from many places around the world,yet, never in Italy. I feel sometimes everything I ever wanted that is food related is available in San Francisco. This pizza , takes you to pizza heaven no matter where you eat it. It so good that it forces you to close your eyes to distinguish the  different ingredients that is being fused in your mouth.
author: Sulaiman B.

description: Beautiful truck, very good Neapolitan pizza.  No complaints.  Will go back.
author: Jon B.

description: My partner & I have been looking for a weekend food event that Del Popolo participated. Just our luck they brought the monster truck to Off the Grid's Presidio Picnic. We shared the Margherita & Bianca pies. Four  generous slices of pizza perfection! Can't wait for next weekend.
author: Lawrence G.

description:
the most creative and innovative food truck i've ever seen thus far. why creative and innovative? well, they transformed a freight container into a movable food truck that carries a woodfire oven that you could only see at italian restaurants like delfina or Italy.

In terms of their pizzas, AWESOMENESS! very rustic and fresh, that's whatsup! plus, it isn't that expensive to get. i got their margherita pizza... a good one should always have the fresh tomates, mozz, basil...and it really is. also, what's best with del popolo is that they MOVE around.. follow em on twitter and you don't need to wait at a restaurant because who would want to during lunch?
author: Marc K.

description: I tried their bianca and margherita at the Presidio last month. It was best pizza I've ever had and I've lived in New York and Boston and have been to Italy. Really. I keep dreaming about that bianca. I downed it. All. In a few minutes. It's probably a good thing I live far from the city.
author: Sistrsprkl S.

description: Split the margherita with a friend ($10 for what's probably meant to be an individual portion, but a generous one at that) and it was a bit oily for my taste. Also a bit bland/didn't really leave an impression. The truck/concept/presentation is pretty awesome, though... and the pizza is still above average.
author: Richa A.

description:
Awesome truck, OK pizza.

2 friends and I split the 3 pizza choices - margarita, white and spicy salami. The white pizza was the best, with the garlic and buttery taste. The margarita lacked some seasoning and I just wanted more spicy salami on the spicy salami. The crust was chewy, which my friend liked but I wish it was more crisp. The bottom and crust had burnt spots, more so than I would have liked. Some mouthfuls were overwhelmed by the burnt taste.

Two days later I was up in Hopland at the new pizzeria/taverna by Campovida - their pizza was much better.
author: Sarah K.

description: I tried del Popolo twice now...same experience.  The crust is not DONE.  The top is charred and the bottom tastes more like a barely done pancake...doughy and flaccid. The toppings are fine. But for $11 and $10 a pop...it should be much much better. AND the second time I had the pizza..did my eyes deceive me...or was the size of pizza received about a 1/3rd less than the time before.  Others at my office who had tried del Poppolo more than once had the same reaction...also there was consensu among the 5+ who partaked ...not worth the price.  Sorry...loved the truck and the pizza making show...but disappointing..
author: michael N.

description:
I've been following this food truck on Twitter for months, awaiting that weekday afternoon I could be in the city at 54 Mint Plaza or in Soma.  Hasn't happened yet but finally went to the Presidio's Off the Grid picnic last Sunday for the express purpose of trying a pie.  The address according to Yelp is 103 Montgomery and somehow my logic was suspended as I drove through the financial district.  Needless to say, a confluence of events a flat tire earlier in the morning, the silly diversion in directions, resulted in  getting to the Presidio at 3:30.  Running up to the glass faced truck (totally awesome-how did they do that? (!) I found some stragglers who informed me that the truck was closed...My mind shrieked..."Noooooo!"  I begged the guy with the bills in hand, who initially chatised me for not coming earlier.  Then Mr. Jonathon Darksy turned around and asked me, did you come out for the Pizza? (this is pizza that deserves a capital "P"). And with that, he bestowed me one of the last pizzas on the rack.  Thank you Mr. Darsky - you are awesome!  P.S.  I'm sorry if I took your lunch!

The Margherita pizzawith its perfectly charred crust  with a slightly sour note to it (like a great bread), a dusting of salt, and a nice thin layer of sauce was delicious.  Like Una pizza napoletana, this type of crust struggles to be crisp in the center but that's something one just accepts as part of the nature of this delicious pie.  

I've recently tried a number of Neopolitan pies in Manhattan from Keste, Co, and Don Antonio by Starita and I can declare with confidence that NYC has nothing over SF pizza!
author: Betty T.

description: I was hoping it would be better.  I've been eating Casey's Pizza (the other pizza truck) for a while and I was hoping this would be on par with Casey's.  Unfortunately, the dough was pretty soggy toward the middle of the pie and the sauce isn't as good (too orange, creamy).  Aside from the somewhat soggy crust, this is pretty good pizza.  They had no meat toppings when I visited, so I can't speak to whether or not they stack up against the Zoe's meats Casey's uses.  The drink selection seemed limited to orange fanta and water, though I heard talk of coca-cola.
author: Lester B.

description: I wouldnt know if the pizza is any good, 30 minutes in line  plus an extra 20 to wait while 5 guys put one by one little pizza in a tiny oven.
author: Nelson S.

description: So a while ago, I traveled to Portland and saw this place (http://www.yelp.com/biz/give-pizza-a-chance-portland) and I thought SF's food truck scene was slipping. About a year later, I see this huge crate being parked around the city with this massive oven and what looked like a dough mixer inside. I had to see for myself (Great job marketing and advertising). Recently I went to the Four Barrel anniversary and smelled the pizza down the block. It looked delicious so I had to try. I had the white pizza. Not something you usually find in SF. Then about 5 minutes later, I received a little four slice pizza. The dough was puffy and not too greasy. The bottom of the pizza was lightly burned and gives it that wood oven taste. The cheese and garlic was pretty good too. I am not sure if I smelled like garlic the rest of the day, but I don't care. It is a little pricey for a small pizza but that's the SF food truck novelty markup tax as I call it. It's a good find if it's in the area and if you are in the mood for pizza.
author: Greg G.

description: Definitely worth any wait you might encounter!  DP's pizzas are the best in San Francisco; great ingredients and phenomenal dough, all served out of an amazing truck.
author: John W.
